water_high_shc_reason.name: Why Water Has High Specific Heat
water_high_shc_reason.correct: Water has a high specific heat capacity because of extensive HYDROGEN BONDING between molecules. More energy is needed to break these bonds and increase molecular motion.

covalent bonds.error: Covalent bonds don't break during heating‚Äîthey're within molecules.
covalent bonds.fix: Heating overcomes intermolecular forces (hydrogen bonds), not intramolecular bonds.
covalent bonds.action: Distinguish: covalent bonds (within H‚ÇÇO) vs hydrogen bonds (between H‚ÇÇO molecules).

ionic bonds.error: Water is covalent, not ionic. There are no ionic bonds in water.
ionic bonds.fix: Water molecules have hydrogen bonds between them, not ionic bonds.
ionic bonds.action: H‚ÇÇO is a covalent molecule with hydrogen bonding between molecules.

dispersion forces.error: Dispersion forces are weak. They don't explain water's high specific heat.
dispersion forces.fix: Water's high c is due to strong HYDROGEN BONDS, not weak dispersion forces.
dispersion forces.action: Compare: alkanes (dispersion only) have much lower c than water.

formula_variables.name: q = mcŒîT Variables
formula_variables.correct: In q = mcŒîT: q is energy (J), m is mass (g), c is specific heat capacity (J g‚Åª¬π ¬∞C‚Åª¬π), and ŒîT is temperature change (¬∞C).

volume.error: Volume is not in the q = mcŒîT formula.
volume.fix: The formula uses MASS (m), not volume. Mass in grams.

moles.action: For moles, use: m = n √ó M, then substitute into q = mcŒîT.

delta_t_calculation.name: Calculating Temperature Change
delta_t_calculation.correct: Temperature change (ŒîT) is calculated as final temperature minus initial temperature. ŒîT can be positive (heating) or negative (cooling).

initial minus final.action: Heating: T goes up, so ŒîT is positive. Final > Initial.

final temperature only.error: You need both temperatures to calculate the change.
final temperature only.fix: ŒîT requires subtraction: final minus initial.
final temperature only.action: Change means difference. You can't have a difference with only one value.

average of temperatures.error: ŒîT is a difference, not an average.
average of temperatures.fix: Don't add and divide. Subtract: ŒîT = T_final ‚àí T_initial.
average of temperatures.action: Delta (Œî) always means change = final ‚àí initial.

1 kJ = 100 J.action: Just like 1 kg = 1000 g, 1 kJ = 1000 J.

calorimetry_purpose.name: Purpose of Calorimetry
calorimetry_purpose.correct: Simple calorimetry uses the temperature change of water to calculate the heat energy released when fuel or food combusts.

measure temperature.error: Calorimetry measures energy, not just temperature.
measure temperature.fix: Temperature change is measured, but the goal is to calculate ENERGY released.
measure temperature.action: Temperature is the data collected. Energy is what we calculate from it.

measure mass loss.error: Mass loss might be recorded, but calorimetry measures heat energy.
measure mass loss.fix: Calorimetry uses q = mcŒîT to find energy from temperature change.
measure mass loss.action: The calorimeter measures heat, using water as the absorbing medium.

measure reaction rate.error: Calorimetry measures heat energy, not rate.
measure reaction rate.fix: Rate experiments measure time. Calorimetry measures energy change.
measure reaction rate.action: Calorimetry = heat measurement. Different from kinetics experiments.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the purpose of different experiments.
persistent.action: Calorimetry = measuring heat energy. Write the definition and key equation.

water_as_medium.name: Why Water is Used in Calorimetry
water_as_medium.correct: Water is used because its HIGH specific heat capacity means it can absorb a lot of energy with only a small temperature change, making measurements more accurate.

low specific heat capacity.error: Opposite. Water has HIGH specific heat capacity.
low specific heat capacity.fix: High c means water absorbs lots of energy per degree rise. This is useful.
low specific heat capacity.action: Water's c = 4.18 J g‚Åª¬π ¬∞C‚Åª¬π is higher than most liquids.

cheap and available.error: While true, this isn't the scientific reason for using water.
cheap and available.fix: The main reason is water's high specific heat capacity.
cheap and available.action: Other liquids are also cheap but aren't as effective for calorimetry.

it doesn't evaporate.error: Water does evaporate. That's actually a source of error.
it doesn't evaporate.fix: Water's advantage is its high c, not evaporation resistance.
it doesn't evaporate.action: Evaporation is a source of heat loss‚Äîa limitation, not an advantage.

persistent.gap: You're not connecting water's properties to its calorimetry use.
persistent.action: High c = absorbs more energy per ¬∞C = better heat sink for measurements.

heat_loss_effect.name: Effect of Heat Loss
heat_loss_effect.correct: Heat loss to the surroundings means the measured energy is LESS than the actual energy released. This gives a lower experimental value.

higher than theoretical.error: Heat loss reduces the measured value, not increases it.
higher than theoretical.fix: Lost heat doesn't reach the water, so less temperature rise occurs.
higher than theoretical.action: If heat escapes, the water heats less ‚Üí q calculated is lower.

no effect.error: Heat loss definitely affects the results.
no effect.fix: Any heat not absorbed by water is 'missing' from the calculation.
no effect.action: This is why experimental values are always less than theoretical.

doubles the result.error: Heat loss decreases the result, not increases it.
doubles the result.fix: Lost energy means measured ŒîT is smaller than it should be.
doubles the result.action: Think: where does lost heat go? Not into the water = not measured.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding how heat loss affects calorimetry.
persistent.action: Draw an energy flow diagram: fuel ‚Üí (some to water, some to surroundings).

approximation_meaning.name: Why Results are Approximations
approximation_meaning.correct: Calorimetry gives an APPROXIMATION because heat is lost to surroundings, combustion may be incomplete, and not all heat transfers to the water.

exact values.error: Simple calorimetry cannot give exact values.
exact values.fix: Multiple sources of error mean results are always approximations.
exact values.action: List error sources: heat loss, incomplete combustion, evaporation.

random measurement.error: Results aren't random‚Äîthey're systematically lower due to heat loss.
random measurement.fix: Systematic errors (heat loss) cause consistent underestimates.
random measurement.action: Approximation ‚â† random. It's a predictable underestimate.

depends on the equipment.error: While equipment matters, fundamental heat loss makes all results approximate.
depends on the equipment.fix: Even good equipment can't prevent all heat loss in simple calorimetry.
depends on the equipment.action: Better equipment reduces error but doesn't eliminate it.

shc_definition.title: Specific Heat Capacity Definition
shc_definition.content: Specific heat capacity (c) is the energy required to raise the temperature of one gram of a substance by one degree Celsius. The word 'specific' indicates it is measured per unit mass (grams), distinguishing it from molar heat capacity (per mole).
keyPoints: Defined as energy per gram per degree Celsius
Units are J g‚Åª¬π ¬∞C‚Åª¬π
Higher c means more energy needed to raise temperature
Different substances have different c values

shc_units.title: Units of Specific Heat Capacity
shc_units.content: The units J g‚Åª¬π ¬∞C‚Åª¬π directly reflect the definition: joules (energy) per gram (mass) per degree Celsius (temperature change). Each component of the unit corresponds to part of the definition.
keyPoints: J = energy component
g‚Åª¬π = per gram of substance
¬∞C‚Åª¬π = per degree of temperature change
All three parts must be present

water_shc_value.title: Water's Specific Heat Capacity
water_shc_value.content: Water has a specific heat capacity of 4.18 J g‚Åª¬π ¬∞C‚Åª¬π, which is unusually high compared to most substances. This makes water excellent for storing thermal energy and for use in calorimetry experiments.
keyPoints: c(H‚ÇÇO) = 4.18 J g‚Åª¬π ¬∞C‚Åª¬π
Higher than most metals and liquids
Essential value for calorimetry calculations
Explains why water heats and cools slowly

water_high_shc_reason.title: Why Water Has High Specific Heat Capacity
water_high_shc_reason.content: Water's high specific heat capacity is due to extensive hydrogen bonding between water molecules. These strong intermolecular forces require additional energy to overcome, meaning more energy is needed to increase molecular motion (temperature).
keyPoints: Hydrogen bonds are strong intermolecular forces
Energy goes into breaking H-bonds, not just increasing motion
This is an intermolecular effect, not intramolecular
Other H-bonding liquids also have relatively high c values

formula_variables.title: The q = mcŒîT Formula
formula_variables.content: The formula q = mcŒîT relates heat energy (q) to mass (m), specific heat capacity (c), and temperature change (ŒîT). This is the fundamental equation for all specific heat calculations.
keyPoints: q = energy in joules (J)
m = mass in grams (g)
c = specific heat capacity in J g‚Åª¬π ¬∞C‚Åª¬π
ŒîT = temperature change in ¬∞C

delta_t_calculation.title: Calculating Temperature Change
delta_t_calculation.content: Temperature change (ŒîT) is calculated as final temperature minus initial temperature. The delta symbol (Œî) always means 'change in', calculated as final minus initial.
keyPoints: Final minus initial, not the other way around
Positive ŒîT = heating (temperature increased)
Negative ŒîT = cooling (temperature decreased)
Must calculate ŒîT before using in q = mcŒîT

energy_units.title: Energy Units and Conversions
energy_units.content: Energy in calorimetry is measured in joules (J) or kilojoules (kJ). Since 'kilo' means thousand, 1 kJ = 1000 J. The formula q = mcŒîT gives energy in joules when c is in J g‚Åª¬π ¬∞C‚Åª¬π.
keyPoints: J to kJ: divide by 1000
kJ to J: multiply by 1000
Always check units match in calculations
Energy content of fuels often given in kJ g‚Åª¬π

calorimetry_purpose.title: Purpose of Simple Calorimetry
calorimetry_purpose.content: Simple calorimetry is an experimental technique to measure the heat energy released during combustion of fuels or food. The heat is absorbed by water, and the temperature change is used to calculate energy using q = mcŒîT.
keyPoints: Measures heat energy from combustion
Uses water as the heat-absorbing medium
Temperature change converted to energy via q = mcŒîT
Results are approximations due to heat loss

water_as_medium.title: Why Water is Used in Calorimetry
water_as_medium.content: Water is the ideal medium for calorimetry because its high specific heat capacity allows it to absorb large amounts of energy with relatively small temperature changes. This makes measurements more accurate and easier to record.
keyPoints: High c = absorbs more energy per degree rise
Stable and non-reactive
Temperature easy to measure accurately
Well-characterised c value (4.18 J g‚Åª¬π ¬∞C‚Åª¬π)

heat_loss_effect.title: Effect of Heat Loss on Results
heat_loss_effect.content: Heat loss to the surroundings means not all energy from combustion reaches the water. This causes experimental energy values to be lower than theoretical values, reducing the measured efficiency of the process.
keyPoints: Heat escapes to air, container, and surroundings
Experimental value < theoretical value
Efficiency = (experimental √∑ theoretical) √ó 100%
Insulation can reduce (but not eliminate) heat loss

approximation_meaning.title: Why Calorimetry Gives Approximations
approximation_meaning.content: Simple calorimetry provides only approximate values because of multiple sources of error: heat loss to surroundings, incomplete combustion of fuel, evaporation of water, and heat absorbed by the container itself.
keyPoints: Heat loss to surroundings is unavoidable
Incomplete combustion releases less energy
Evaporation removes heat from the system
Container absorbs some heat
